down to a conflict between the way in which AWS achieves this promise of
elasticity and a legacy issue that our predecessors really never solved which
is the idea of static IPS because we've got this huge DNS infrastructure right that has been around for as long as the

where we run into that elasticity problem again because when we're deploying an application load balancer or its predecessor the classic eld we're
making a promise we're saying anytime someone's going to look up the IP address of our web service we're going
to actually query this DNS address that corresponds to that load balancer and we're going to get back a couple of

IPs they'll be returned by that result and as you scale back down some of those IPS will disappear so we can't make any

know reality often has other plans so what are some of the legacy issues we
run into well I've touched on one already the idea of a legacy firewall rather than having something like an outbound squid

only allows us to allow access or deny access via IP ranges that's very
difficult if the IPS that are coming back from your load there could be all over the IP space that Amazon owns there's also problems
with people who are following old resolution methods I haven't actually narrowed down explicitly where this
comes from but a couple of different platforms there's there's some Java platforms I've run into and some Windows
platforms that seem to have a strange habit of caching IPs like after it looks
up a DNS record it will cache that IP and not try to look it up again regardless of what the TTL is that's

also have problems with monolithic applications when reporting these things to a highly available deployment this is
something I see a lot with some of the some legacy Java applications that use a in-memory session database we have this

sites on a single IP address or a potentially a single variably changing
IP address so all these things can be addressed with the tools that AWS provides but it may not be immediately
